parameter.parameter_description: the offset in the first buffer from where the new buffer should start.

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: the total length of the new buffer.

function.return: the new #GstBuffer that spans the two source buffers, or NULL if the arguments are invalid.

function.name: gst_buffer_stamp
function.description:
Copies additional information (the timestamp, duration, and offset start and end) from one buffer to the other.
This function does not copy any buffer flags or caps and is equivalent to gst_buffer_copy_metadata(@dest, @src, GST_BUFFER_COPY_TIMESTAMPS).
Deprecated: use gst_buffer_copy_metadata() instead, it provides more control.

function.name: gst_buffer_straw_get_buffer
function.description:
Get one buffer from @pad. Implemented via buffer probes. This function will block until the pipeline passes a buffer over @pad, so for robust behavior in unit tests, you need to use check's timeout to fail out in the case that a buffer never arrives.
You must have previously called gst_buffer_straw_start_pipeline() on @pipeline and @pad.

parameter.name: bin
parameter.parameter_description: the pipeline previously started via gst_buffer_straw_start_pipeline()

parameter.name: pad
parameter.parameter_description: the pad previously passed to gst_buffer_straw_start_pipeline()

function.return: the captured #GstBuffer.

function.name: gst_buffer_straw_start_pipeline
function.description:
Sets up a pipeline for buffer sucking. This will allow you to call gst_buffer_straw_get_buffer() to access buffers as they pass over @pad.
This function is normally used in unit tests that want to verify that a particular element is outputting correct buffers. For example, you would make a pipeline via gst_parse_launch(), pull out the pad you want to monitor, then call gst_buffer_straw_get_buffer() to get the buffers that pass through @pad. The pipeline will block until you have sucked off the buffers.
This function will set the state of @bin to PLAYING; to clean up, be sure to call gst_buffer_straw_stop_pipeline().
Note that you may not start two buffer straws at the same time. This function is intended for unit tests, not general API use. In fact it calls fail_if from libcheck, so you cannot use it outside unit tests.

parameter.name: pad
parameter.parameter_description: a pad on an element in @bin

function.name: gst_buffer_straw_stop_pipeline
function.description:
Set @bin to #GST_STATE_NULL and release resource allocated in gst_buffer_straw_start_pipeline().
You must have previously called gst_buffer_straw_start_pipeline() on @pipeline and @pad.

parameter.name: bin
parameter.parameter_description: the pipeline previously started via gst_buffer_straw_start_pipeline()

parameter.name: pad
parameter.parameter_description: the pad previously passed to gst_buffer_straw_start_pipeline()

function.name: gst_buffer_try_new_and_alloc
function.description:
Tries to create a newly allocated buffer with data of the given size. If the requested amount of memory can't be allocated, NULL will be returned. The buffer memory is not cleared.
Note that when @size == 0, the buffer data pointer will be NULL.
MT safe.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: the size in bytes of the new buffer's data.

function.return: a new #GstBuffer, or NULL if the memory couldn't be allocated.

function.name: gst_bus_add_signal_watch
function.description:
Adds a bus signal watch to the default main context with the default priority (%G_PRIORITY_DEFAULT). Since 0.10.33 it is also possible to use a non-default main context set up using g_main_context_push_thread_default() (before one had to create a bus watch source and attach it to the desired main context 'manually').
After calling this statement, the bus will emit the "message" signal for each message posted on the bus.
This function may be called multiple times. To clean up, the caller is responsible for calling gst_bus_remove_signal_watch() as many times as this function is called.
MT safe.

parameter.name: bus
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstBus on which you want to receive the "message" signal

function.name: gst_bus_add_signal_watch_full
function.description:
Adds a bus signal watch to the default main context with the given @priority (e.g. %G_PRIORITY_DEFAULT). Since 0.10.33 it is also possible to use a non-default main context set up using g_main_context_push_thread_default() (before one had to create a bus watch source and attach it to the desired main context 'manually').
After calling this statement, the bus will emit the "message" signal for each message posted on the bus when the main loop is running.
This function may be called multiple times. To clean up, the caller is responsible for calling gst_bus_remove_signal_watch() as many times as this function is called.
There can only be a single bus watch per bus, you most remove all signal watch before you can set another type of watch.
MT safe.

parameter.name: bus
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstBus on which you want to receive the "message" signal

function.name: gst_bus_add_watch
function.description:
Adds a bus watch to the default main context with the default priority (%G_PRIORITY_DEFAULT). Since 0.10.33 it is also possible to use a non-default main context set up using g_main_context_push_thread_default() (before one had to create a bus watch source and attach it to the desired main context 'manually').
This function is used to receive asynchronous messages in the main loop. There can only be a single bus watch per bus, you must remove it before you can set a new one.
The watch can be removed using g_source_remove() or by returning FALSE from @func.

parameter.name: bus
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstBus to create the watch for

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: A function to call when a message is received.

function.return:
The event source id.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_bus_add_watch_full
function.description:
Adds a bus watch to the default main context with the given @priority (e.g. %G_PRIORITY_DEFAULT). Since 0.10.33 it is also possible to use a non-default main context set up using g_main_context_push_thread_default() (before one had to create a bus watch source and attach it to the desired main context 'manually').
This function is used to receive asynchronous messages in the main loop. There can only be a single bus watch per bus, you must remove it before you can set a new one.
When @func is called, the message belongs to the caller; if you want to keep a copy of it, call gst_message_ref() before leaving @func.
The watch can be removed using g_source_remove() or by returning FALSE from @func.

parameter.name: bus
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstBus to create the watch for.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: A function to call when a message is received.

parameter.name: notify
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call when the source is removed.

function.return:
The event source id.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_bus_async_signal_func
function.description: A helper #GstBusFunc that can be used to convert all asynchronous messages into signals.
function.return: TRUE

function.name: gst_bus_create_watch
function.description: Create watch for this bus. The GSource will be dispatched whenever a message is on the bus. After the GSource is dispatched, the message is popped off the bus and unreffed.

parameter.name: bus
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstBus to create the watch for

function.return: a #GSource that can be added to a mainloop.

function.name: gst_bus_disable_sync_message_emission
function.description:
Instructs GStreamer to stop emitting the "sync-message" signal for this bus. See gst_bus_enable_sync_message_emission() for more information.
In the event that multiple pieces of code have called gst_bus_enable_sync_message_emission(), the sync-message emissions will only be stopped after all calls to gst_bus_enable_sync_message_emission() were "cancelled" by calling this function. In this way the semantics are exactly the same as gst_object_ref() that which calls enable should also call disable.
MT safe.

parameter.name: bus
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstBus on which you previously called gst_bus_enable_sync_message_emission()

function.name: gst_bus_enable_sync_message_emission
function.description:
Instructs GStreamer to emit the "sync-message" signal after running the bus's sync handler. This function is here so that code can ensure that they can synchronously receive messages without having to affect what the bin's sync handler is.
This function may be called multiple times. To clean up, the caller is responsible for calling gst_bus_disable_sync_message_emission() as many times as this function is called.
While this function looks similar to gst_bus_add_signal_watch(), it is not exactly the same -- this function enables <emphasis>synchronous</emphasis> emission of signals when messages arrive; gst_bus_add_signal_watch() adds an idle callback to pop messages off the bus <emphasis>asynchronously</emphasis>. The sync-message signal comes from the thread of whatever object posted the message; the "message" signal is marshalled to the main thread via the main loop.
MT safe.

parameter.name: bus
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstBus on which you want to receive the "sync-message" signal

function.name: gst_bus_have_pending
function.description: Check if there are pending messages on the bus that should be handled.
function.return:
TRUE if there are messages on the bus to be handled, FALSE otherwise.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_bus_new
function.description: Creates a new #GstBus instance.
function.return: a new #GstBus instance

function.name: gst_bus_peek
function.description: Peek the message on the top of the bus' queue. The message will remain on the bus' message queue. A reference is returned, and needs to be unreffed by the caller.
function.return:
the #GstMessage that is on the bus, or NULL if the bus is empty.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_bus_poll
function.description:
Poll the bus for messages. Will block while waiting for messages to come. You can specify a maximum time to poll with the @timeout parameter. If @timeout is negative, this function will block indefinitely.
All messages not in @events will be popped off the bus and will be ignored.
Because poll is implemented using the "message" signal enabled by gst_bus_add_signal_watch(), calling gst_bus_poll() will cause the "message" signal to be emitted for every message that poll sees. Thus a "message" signal handler will see the same messages that this function sees -- neither will steal messages from the other.
This function will run a main loop from the default main context when polling.
You should never use this function, since it is pure evil. This is especially true for GUI applications based on Gtk+ or Qt, but also for any other non-trivial application that uses the GLib main loop. As this function runs a GLib main loop, any callback attached to the default GLib main context may be invoked. This could be timeouts, GUI events, I/O events etc.; even if gst_bus_poll() is called with a 0 timeout. Any of these callbacks may do things you do not expect, e.g. destroy the main application window or some other resource; change other application state; display a dialog and run another main loop until the user clicks it away. In short, using this function may add a lot of complexity to your code through unexpected re-entrancy and unexpected changes to your application's state.
For 0 timeouts use gst_bus_pop_filtered() instead of this function; for other short timeouts use gst_bus_timed_pop_filtered(); everything else is better handled by setting up an asynchronous bus watch and doing things from there.

parameter.name: events
parameter.parameter_description: a mask of #GstMessageType, representing the set of message types to poll for.

parameter.name: timeout
parameter.parameter_description: the poll timeout, as a #GstClockTimeDiff, or -1 to poll indefinitely.

function.return: the message that was received, or NULL if the poll timed out. The message is taken from the bus and needs to be unreffed with gst_message_unref() after usage.

function.name: gst_bus_pop
function.description: Get a message from the bus.
function.return:
the #GstMessage that is on the bus, or NULL if the bus is empty. The message is taken from the bus and needs to be unreffed with gst_message_unref() after usage.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_bus_pop_filtered
function.description: Get a message matching @type from the bus. Will discard all messages on the bus that do not match @type and that have been posted before the first message that does match @type. If there is no message matching @type on the bus, all messages will be discarded.

parameter.name: types
parameter.parameter_description: message types to take into account

function.return:
the next #GstMessage matching @type that is on the bus, or NULL if the bus is empty or there is no message matching @type. The message is taken from the bus and needs to be unreffed with gst_message_unref() after usage.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_bus_post
function.description: Post a message on the given bus. Ownership of the message is taken by the bus.
function.return:
TRUE if the message could be posted, FALSE if the bus is flushing.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_bus_remove_signal_watch
function.description:
Removes a signal watch previously added with gst_bus_add_signal_watch().
MT safe.

parameter.name: bus
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstBus you previously added a signal watch to

function.name: gst_bus_set_flushing
function.description:
If @flushing, flush out and unref any messages queued in the bus. Releases references to the message origin objects. Will flush future messages until gst_bus_set_flushing() sets @flushing to #FALSE.
MT safe.

parameter.name: flushing
parameter.parameter_description: whether or not to flush the bus

function.name: gst_bus_set_sync_handler
function.description:
Sets the synchronous handler on the bus. The function will be called every time a new message is posted on the bus. Note that the function will be called in the same thread context as the posting object. This function is usually only called by the creator of the bus. Applications should handle messages asynchronously using the gst_bus watch and poll functions.
You cannot replace an existing sync_handler. You can pass NULL to this function, which will clear the existing handler.

parameter.name: bus
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstBus to install the handler on

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: User data that will be sent to the handler function.

function.name: gst_bus_sync_signal_handler
function.description: A helper GstBusSyncHandler that can be used to convert all synchronous messages into signals.
function.return: GST_BUS_PASS

function.name: gst_bus_timed_pop
function.description:
Get a message from the bus, waiting up to the specified timeout.
If @timeout is 0, this function behaves like gst_bus_pop(). If @timeout is #GST_CLOCK_TIME_NONE, this function will block forever until a message was posted on the bus.
function.return:
the #GstMessage that is on the bus after the specified timeout or NULL if the bus is empty after the timeout expired. The message is taken from the bus and needs to be unreffed with gst_message_unref() after usage.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_bus_timed_pop_filtered
function.description:
Get a message from the bus whose type matches the message type mask @types, waiting up to the specified timeout (and discarding any messages that do not match the mask provided).
If @timeout is 0, this function behaves like gst_bus_pop_filtered(). If @timeout is #GST_CLOCK_TIME_NONE, this function will block forever until a matching message was posted on the bus.

parameter.name: timeout
parameter.parameter_description: a timeout in nanoseconds, or GST_CLOCK_TIME_NONE to wait forever

parameter.name: types
parameter.parameter_description: message types to take into account, GST_MESSAGE_ANY for any type

function.return:
a #GstMessage matching the filter in @types, or NULL if no matching message was found on the bus until the timeout expired. The message is taken from the bus and needs to be unreffed with gst_message_unref() after usage.
MT safe.

Free-function: g_free

function.name: gst_byte_reader_init

parameter.parameter_description: data from which the #GstByteReader should read

function.name: gst_byte_reader_init_from_buffer
function.description: Initializes a #GstByteReader instance to read from @buffer. This function can be called on already initialized instances.

parameter.name: buffer
parameter.parameter_description: Buffer from which the #GstByteReader should read

function.name: gst_byte_reader_masked_scan_uint32
function.description:
Scan for pattern @pattern with applied mask @mask in the byte reader data, starting from offset @offset relative to the current position.
The bytes in @pattern and @mask are interpreted left-to-right, regardless of endianness. All four bytes of the pattern must be present in the byte reader data for it to match, even if the first or last bytes are masked out.
It is an error to call this function without making sure that there is enough data (offset+size bytes) in the byte reader.

parameter.name: mask
parameter.parameter_description: mask to apply to data before matching against @pattern

parameter.name: pattern
parameter.parameter_description: pattern to match (after mask is applied)

parameter.name: offset
parameter.parameter_description: offset from which to start scanning, relative to the current position

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: number of bytes to scan from offset

function.name: gst_byte_reader_peek_string
function.description:
Returns a constant pointer to the current data position if there is a NUL-terminated string in the data (this could be just a NUL terminator). The current position will be maintained. This will work for any NUL-terminated string with a character width of 8 bits, so ASCII, UTF-8, ISO-8859-N etc.
This function will fail if no NUL-terminator was found in in the data.

parameter.name: str
parameter.parameter_description: address of a #gchar pointer varieble in which to store the result

function.return: %TRUE if a string could be skipped, %FALSE otherwise.

No input checking for valid UTF-8 is done.

function.description:
Skips a NUL-terminated string in the #GstByteReader instance, advancing the current position to the byte after the string. This will work for any NUL-terminated string with a character width of 8 bits, so ASCII, UTF-8, ISO-8859-N etc.
This function will fail if no NUL-terminator was found in in the data.
function.return: %TRUE if a string could be skipped, %FALSE otherwise.

No input checking for valid UTF-16 is done.
This function will fail if no NUL-terminator was found in in the data.
function.return: %TRUE if a string could be skipped, %FALSE otherwise.

Skips a NUL-terminated UTF-32 string in the #GstByteReader instance, advancing the current position to the byte after the string.
No input checking for valid UTF-32 is done.
This function will fail if no NUL-terminator was found in in the data.

function.description: Writes @size bytes containing @value to @writer.

parameter.parameter_description: Number of bytes to be writen

function.description:
Frees @writer and all memory allocated by it except the current data, which is returned as #GstBuffer.
Free-function: gst_buffer_unref

Frees @writer and all memory allocated by it except the current data, which is returned.

function.name: gst_byte_writer_get_remaining
function.description: Returns the remaining size of data that can still be written. If -1 is returned the remaining size is only limited by system resources.

function.description: Initializes @writer to an empty instance

function.name: gst_byte_writer_init_with_buffer
function.description:
Initializes @writer with the given buffer. If @initialized is %TRUE it is possible to read the complete buffer from the #GstByteWriter from the beginning.
<note>@buffer must be writable</note>

parameter.name: initialized
parameter.parameter_description: If %TRUE the complete data can be read from the beginning

function.name: gst_byte_writer_init_with_data
function.description: Initializes @writer with the given memory area. If @initialized is %TRUE it is possible to read @size bytes from the #GstByteWriter from the beginning.

parameter.name: initialized
parameter.parameter_description: If %TRUE the complete data can be read from the beginning

function.name: gst_byte_writer_init_with_size
function.description: Initializes @writer with the given initial data size.

parameter.name: fixed
parameter.parameter_description: If %TRUE the data can't be reallocated

function.name: gst_byte_writer_new
function.description:
Creates a new, empty #GstByteWriter instance
Free-function: gst_byte_writer_free
function.return: a new, empty #GstByteWriter instance

function.name: gst_byte_writer_new_with_buffer
function.description:
Creates a new #GstByteWriter instance with the given buffer. If @initialized is %TRUE it is possible to read the complete buffer from the #GstByteWriter from the beginning.
<note>@buffer must be writable</note>
Free-function: gst_byte_writer_free

parameter.name: initialized
parameter.parameter_description: If %TRUE the complete data can be read from the beginning

function.return: a new #GstByteWriter instance

function.name: gst_byte_writer_new_with_data
function.description:
Creates a new #GstByteWriter instance with the given memory area. If @initialized is %TRUE it is possible to read @size bytes from the #GstByteWriter from the beginning.
Free-function: gst_byte_writer_free

parameter.name: initialized
parameter.parameter_description: If %TRUE the complete data can be read from the beginning

function.return: a new #GstByteWriter instance

function.name: gst_byte_writer_new_with_size
function.description:
Creates a new #GstByteWriter instance with the given initial data size.
Free-function: gst_byte_writer_free

parameter.name: fixed
parameter.parameter_description: If %TRUE the data can't be reallocated

function.return: a new #GstByteWriter instance

function.name: gst_byte_writer_reset
function.description: Resets @writer and frees the data if it's owned by @writer.

function.name: gst_byte_writer_reset_and_get_buffer
function.description:
Resets @writer and returns the current data as buffer.
Free-function: gst_buffer_unref
function.return: the current data as buffer. gst_buffer_unref() after usage.

function.name: gst_byte_writer_reset_and_get_data
function.description:
Resets @writer and returns the current data.
Free-function: g_free
function.return: the current data. g_free() after usage.

function.name: gst_caps_append

parameter.name: caps1
parameter.parameter_description: the #GstCaps that will be appended to

function.name: gst_caps_append_structure
function.description: Appends @structure to @caps. The structure is not copied; @caps becomes the owner of @structure.

parameter.name: caps
parameter.parameter_description: the #GstCaps that will be appended to

function.name: gst_caps_can_intersect
function.description: Tries intersecting @caps1 and @caps2 and reports whether the result would not be empty
function.return: %TRUE if intersection would be not empty

function.name: gst_caps_copy
function.description:
Creates a new #GstCaps as a copy of the old @caps. The new caps will have a refcount of 1, owned by the caller. The structures are copied as well.
Note that this function is the semantic equivalent of a gst_caps_ref() followed by a gst_caps_make_writable(). If you only want to hold on to a reference to the data, you should use gst_caps_ref().
When you are finished with the caps, call gst_caps_unref() on it.
function.return: the new #GstCaps

function.name: gst_caps_copy_nth
function.description: Creates a new #GstCaps and appends a copy of the nth structure contained in @caps.
function.return: the new #GstCaps

function.name: gst_caps_do_simplify
function.description: Modifies the given @caps inplace into a representation that represents the same set of formats, but in a simpler form. Component structures that are identical are merged. Component structures that have values that can be merged are also merged.
function.return: TRUE, if the caps could be simplified

function.name: gst_caps_from_string
function.description: Converts @caps from a string representation.
function.return: a newly allocated #GstCaps

function.name: gst_caps_get_size
function.description: Gets the number of structures contained in @caps.
function.return: the number of structures that @caps contains

function.name: gst_caps_get_structure
function.description:
Finds the structure in @caps that has the index @index, and returns it.
WARNING: This function takes a const GstCaps *, but returns a non-const GstStructure *. This is for programming convenience -- the caller should be aware that structures inside a constant #GstCaps should not be modified. However, if you know the caps are writable, either because you have just copied them or made them writable with gst_caps_make_writable(), you may modify the structure returned in the usual way, e.g. with functions like gst_structure_set().
You do not need to free or unref the structure returned, it belongs to the #GstCaps.
function.return: a pointer to the #GstStructure corresponding to @index

function.name: gst_caps_intersect
function.description: Creates a new #GstCaps that contains all the formats that are common to both @caps1 and @caps2. Defaults to %GST_CAPS_INTERSECT_ZIG_ZAG mode.
function.return: the new #GstCaps

function.name: gst_caps_intersect_first
function.description:
Creates a new #GstCaps that contains all the formats that are common to both @caps1 and @caps2.
Unlike @gst_caps_intersect, the returned caps will be ordered in a similar fashion as @caps1.
function.return: the new #GstCaps

function.name: gst_caps_intersect_full
function.description: Creates a new #GstCaps that contains all the formats that are common to both @caps1 and @caps2, the order is defined by the #GstCapsIntersectMode used.
function.return: the new #GstCaps

function.name: gst_caps_is_always_compatible
function.description: A given #GstCaps structure is always compatible with another if every media format that is in the first is also contained in the second. That is, @caps1 is a subset of @caps2.
function.return: TRUE if @caps1 is a subset of @caps2.

function.name: gst_caps_is_any
function.description: Determines if @caps represents any media format.
function.return: TRUE if @caps represents any format.

function.name: gst_caps_is_empty
function.description: Determines if @caps represents no media formats.
function.return: TRUE if @caps represents no formats.

function.name: gst_caps_is_equal
function.description:
Checks if the given caps represent the same set of caps. <note>This function does not work reliably if optional properties for caps are included on one caps and omitted on the other.</note>
This function deals correctly with passing NULL for any of the caps.
function.return: TRUE if both caps are equal.

function.name: gst_caps_is_equal_fixed
function.description: Tests if two #GstCaps are equal. This function only works on fixed #GstCaps.
function.return: TRUE if the arguments represent the same format

function.name: gst_caps_is_fixed
function.description: Fixed #GstCaps describe exactly one format, that is, they have exactly one structure, and each field in the structure describes a fixed type. Examples of non-fixed types are GST_TYPE_INT_RANGE and GST_TYPE_LIST.
function.return: TRUE if @caps is fixed

function.name: gst_caps_is_subset
function.description: Checks if all caps represented by @subset are also represented by @superset. <note>This function does not work reliably if optional properties for caps are included on one caps and omitted on the other.</note>
function.return: %TRUE if @subset is a subset of @superset

function.name: gst_caps_load_thyself
function.description: Creates a #GstCaps from its XML serialization.
function.return: a new #GstCaps structure

function.name: gst_caps_make_writable
function.description:
Returns a writable copy of @caps.
If there is only one reference count on @caps, the caller must be the owner, and so this function will return the caps object unchanged. If on the other hand there is more than one reference on the object, a new caps object will be returned. The caller's reference on @caps will be removed, and instead the caller will own a reference to the returned object.
In short, this function unrefs the caps in the argument and refs the caps that it returns. Don't access the argument after calling this function. See also: gst_caps_ref().
function.return: the same #GstCaps object.

function.name: gst_caps_merge
function.description: Appends the structures contained in @caps2 to @caps1 if they are not yet expressed by @caps1. The structures in @caps2 are not copied -- they are transferred to @caps1, and then @caps2 is freed. If either caps is ANY, the resulting caps will be ANY.

parameter.name: caps1
parameter.parameter_description: the #GstCaps that will take the new entries

function.name: gst_caps_merge_structure
function.description: Appends @structure to @caps if its not already expressed by @caps. The structure is not copied; @caps becomes the owner of @structure.

parameter.name: caps
parameter.parameter_description: the #GstCaps that will the the new structure

function.name: gst_caps_new_any
function.description: Creates a new #GstCaps that indicates that it is compatible with any media format.
function.return: the new #GstCaps

function.name: gst_caps_new_empty
function.description: Creates a new #GstCaps that is empty. That is, the returned #GstCaps contains no media formats. Caller is responsible for unreffing the returned caps.
function.return: the new #GstCaps

function.name: gst_caps_new_full
function.description: Creates a new #GstCaps and adds all the structures listed as arguments. The list must be NULL-terminated. The structures are not copied; the returned #GstCaps owns the structures.
function.return: the new #GstCaps

function.name: gst_caps_new_full_valist
function.description: Creates a new #GstCaps and adds all the structures listed as arguments. The list must be NULL-terminated. The structures are not copied; the returned #GstCaps owns the structures.
function.return: the new #GstCaps

function.name: gst_caps_new_simple
function.description: Creates a new #GstCaps that contains one #GstStructure. The structure is defined by the arguments, which have the same format as gst_structure_new(). Caller is responsible for unreffing the returned caps.

parameter.name: media_type
parameter.parameter_description: the media type of the structure

function.return: the new #GstCaps

function.name: gst_caps_normalize
function.return: the new #GstCaps

function.name: gst_caps_ref
function.description:
Add a reference to a #GstCaps object.
From this point on, until the caller calls gst_caps_unref() or gst_caps_make_writable(), it is guaranteed that the caps object will not change. This means its structures won't change, etc. To use a #GstCaps object, you must always have a refcount on it -- either the one made implicitly by e.g. gst_caps_new_simple(), or via taking one explicitly with this function.
function.return: the same #GstCaps object.

function.name: gst_caps_remove_structure
function.description: removes the stucture with the given index from the list of structures contained in @caps.

parameter.name: idx
parameter.parameter_description: Index of the structure to remove

function.name: gst_caps_replace
function.description:
Replaces *caps with @newcaps. Unrefs the #GstCaps in the location pointed to by @caps, if applicable, then modifies @caps to point to @newcaps. An additional ref on @newcaps is taken.
This function does not take any locks so you might want to lock the object owning @caps pointer.

function.name: gst_caps_save_thyself
function.description: Serializes a #GstCaps to XML and adds it as a child node of @parent.
function.return: a XML node pointer

function.name: gst_caps_set_simple
function.description: Sets fields in a #GstCaps. The arguments must be passed in the same manner as gst_structure_set(), and be NULL-terminated. <note>Prior to GStreamer version 0.10.26, this function failed when @caps was not simple. If your code needs to work with those versions of GStreamer, you may only call this function when GST_CAPS_IS_SIMPLE() is %TRUE for @caps.</note>

function.name: gst_caps_set_simple_valist
function.description: Sets fields in a #GstCaps. The arguments must be passed in the same manner as gst_structure_set(), and be NULL-terminated. <note>Prior to GStreamer version 0.10.26, this function failed when @caps was not simple. If your code needs to work with those versions of GStreamer, you may only call this function when GST_CAPS_IS_SIMPLE() is %TRUE for @caps.</note>

function.name: gst_caps_set_value
function.description: Sets the given @field on all structures of @caps to the given @value. This is a convenience function for calling gst_structure_set_value() on all structures of @caps.

parameter.name: field
parameter.parameter_description: name of the field to set

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: value to set the field to

function.name: gst_caps_steal_structure
function.description: Retrieves the stucture with the given index from the list of structures contained in @caps. The caller becomes the owner of the returned structure.

parameter.name: index
parameter.parameter_description: Index of the structure to retrieve

function.return: a pointer to the #GstStructure corresponding to @index.

function.name: gst_caps_subtract
function.description: Subtracts the @subtrahend from the @minuend. <note>This function does not work reliably if optional properties for caps are included on one caps and omitted on the other.</note>
function.return: the resulting caps

function.name: gst_caps_to_string
function.description:
Converts @caps to a string representation. This string representation can be converted back to a #GstCaps by gst_caps_from_string().
For debugging purposes its easier to do something like this: |[ GST_LOG ("caps are %" GST_PTR_FORMAT, caps); ]| This prints the caps in human readble form.
function.return: a newly allocated string representing @caps.

function.name: gst_caps_truncate
function.description: Destructively discard all but the first structure from @caps. Useful when fixating. @caps must be writable.

function.name: gst_caps_union
function.description: Creates a new #GstCaps that contains all the formats that are in either @caps1 and @caps2.
function.return: the new #GstCaps

function.name: gst_caps_unref
function.description: Unref a #GstCaps and and free all its structures and the structures' values when the refcount reaches 0.

function.name: gst_cdda_base_src_add_track
function.description: CDDA sources use this function from their start vfunc to announce the available data and audio tracks to the base source class. The caller should allocate @track on the stack, the base source will do a shallow copy of the structure (and take ownership of the taglist if there is one).
function.return: FALSE on error, otherwise TRUE.

function.name: gst_check_caps_equal
function.description: Compare two caps with gst_caps_is_equal and fail unless they are equal.

function.name: gst_check_drop_buffers
function.description: Unref and remove all buffers that are in the global @buffers GList, emptying the list.

function.name: gst_check_element_push_buffer
function.description: Create an @element with the factory with the name and push the @buffer_in to this element. The element should create one buffer and this will be compared with @buffer_out. We only check the caps and the data of the buffers. This function unrefs the buffers.

parameter.name: element_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of the element that needs to be created

parameter.name: buffer_in
parameter.parameter_description: push this buffer to the element

parameter.name: buffer_out
parameter.parameter_description: compare the result with this buffer

function.name: gst_check_element_push_buffer_list
function.description: Create an @element with the factory with the name and push the buffers in @buffer_in to this element. The element should create the buffers equal to the buffers in @buffer_out. We only check the caps, size and the data of the buffers. This function unrefs the buffers in the two lists. The last_flow_return parameter indicates the expected flow return value from pushing the final buffer in the list. This can be used to set up a test which pushes some buffers and then an invalid buffer, when the final buffer is expected to fail, for example.

parameter.name: element_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of the element that needs to be created

parameter.name: buffer_in
parameter.parameter_description: a list of buffers that needs to be puched to the element

parameter.name: buffer_out
parameter.parameter_description: a list of buffers that we expect from the element

parameter.name: last_flow_return
parameter.parameter_description: the last buffer push needs to give this GstFlowReturn

function.name: gst_child_proxy_child_added
function.description: Emits the "child-added" signal.

function.name: gst_child_proxy_child_removed
function.description: Emits the "child-removed" signal.

function.name: gst_child_proxy_get
function.description: Gets properties of the parent object and its children.

parameter.name: first_property_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of the first property to get

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the first property, followed optionally by more name/return location pairs, followed by NULL

function.name: gst_child_proxy_get_child_by_index
function.description: Fetches a child by its number.

parameter.name: parent
parameter.parameter_description: the parent object to get the child from

parameter.name: index
parameter.parameter_description: the childs position in the child list

function.return:
the child object or %NULL if not found (index too high). Unref after usage.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_child_proxy_get_child_by_name
function.description:
Looks up a child element by the given name.
Implementors can use #GstObject together with gst_object_get_name()

parameter.name: parent
parameter.parameter_description: the parent object to get the child from

function.return:
the child object or %NULL if not found. Unref after usage.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_child_proxy_get_children_count
function.description: Gets the number of child objects this parent contains.
function.return:
the number of child objects
MT safe.

function.name: gst_child_proxy_get_property
function.description: Gets a single property using the GstChildProxy mechanism. You are responsible for for freeing it by calling g_value_unset()

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: a #GValue that should take the result.

function.name: gst_child_proxy_get_valist
function.description: Gets properties of the parent object and its children.

parameter.name: first_property_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of the first property to get

parameter.name: var_args
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the first property, followed optionally by more name/return location pairs, followed by NULL

function.name: gst_child_proxy_lookup
function.description: Looks up which object and #GParamSpec would be effected by the given @name.

parameter.name: object
parameter.parameter_description: object to lookup the property in

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: name of the property to look up

parameter.name: target
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to a #GstObject that takes the real object to set property on

parameter.name: pspec
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to take the #GParamSpec describing the property

function.return:
TRUE if @target and @pspec could be found. FALSE otherwise. In that case the values for @pspec and @target are not modified. Unref @target after usage.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_child_proxy_set
function.description: Sets properties of the parent object and its children.

parameter.name: first_property_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of the first property to set

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: value for the first property, followed optionally by more name/value pairs, followed by NULL

function.name: gst_child_proxy_set_property
function.description: Sets a single property using the GstChildProxy mechanism.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: name of the property to set

function.name: gst_child_proxy_set_valist
function.description: Sets properties of the parent object and its children.

parameter.name: first_property_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of the first property to set

parameter.name: var_args
parameter.parameter_description: value for the first property, followed optionally by more name/value pairs, followed by NULL

function.name: gst_class_signal_connect
function.description: Connect to a class signal.

parameter.name: klass
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstObjectClass to attach the signal to

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the signal to attach to

function.return: the signal id.

function.name: gst_class_signal_emit_by_name
function.description: emits the named class signal.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the signal to emit

function.name: gst_clock_add_observation
function.description:
The time @master of the master clock and the time @slave of the slave clock are added to the list of observations. If enough observations are available, a linear regression algorithm is run on the observations and @clock is recalibrated.
If this functions returns %TRUE, @r_squared will contain the correlation coefficient of the interpolation. A value of 1.0 means a perfect regression was performed. This value can be used to control the sampling frequency of the master and slave clocks.

parameter.name: r_squared
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to hold the result

function.return:
%TRUE if enough observations were added to run the regression algorithm.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_clock_adjust_unlocked
function.description:
Converts the given @internal clock time to the external time, adjusting for the rate and reference time set with gst_clock_set_calibration() and making sure that the returned time is increasing. This function should be called with the clock's OBJECT_LOCK held and is mainly used by clock subclasses.
This function is the reverse of gst_clock_unadjust_unlocked().
function.return: the converted time of the clock.

function.name: gst_clock_get_calibration

parameter.name: internal
parameter.parameter_description: a location to store the internal time

parameter.name: external
parameter.parameter_description: a location to store the external time

parameter.name: rate_num
parameter.parameter_description: a location to store the rate numerator

parameter.name: rate_denom
parameter.parameter_description: a location to store the rate denominator

function.name: gst_clock_get_internal_time
function.description: Gets the current internal time of the given clock. The time is returned unadjusted for the offset and the rate.
function.return:
the internal time of the clock. Or GST_CLOCK_TIME_NONE when given invalid input.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_clock_get_master
function.description: Get the master clock that @clock is slaved to or %NULL when the clock is not slaved to any master clock.
function.return:
a master #GstClock or %NULL when this clock is not slaved to a master clock. Unref after usage.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_clock_get_resolution
function.description: Get the accuracy of the clock. The accuracy of the clock is the granularity of the values returned by gst_clock_get_time().
function.return:
the resolution of the clock in units of #GstClockTime.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_clock_get_time
function.description: Gets the current time of the given clock. The time is always monotonically increasing and adjusted according to the current offset and rate.
function.return:
the time of the clock. Or GST_CLOCK_TIME_NONE when given invalid input.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_clock_id_compare_func
function.description: Compares the two #GstClockID instances. This function can be used as a GCompareFunc when sorting ids.
function.return:
negative value if a < b; zero if a = b; positive value if a > b
MT safe.

function.name: gst_clock_id_get_time
function.description: Get the time of the clock ID
function.return:
the time of the given clock id.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_clock_id_ref
function.description: Increase the refcount of given @id.
function.return:
The same #GstClockID with increased refcount.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_clock_id_unref
function.description:
Unref given @id. When the refcount reaches 0 the #GstClockID will be freed.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_clock_id_unschedule
function.description:
Cancel an outstanding request with @id. This can either be an outstanding async notification or a pending sync notification. After this call, @id cannot be used anymore to receive sync or async notifications, you need to create a new #GstClockID.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_clock_id_wait
function.description:
Perform a blocking wait on @id. @id should have been created with gst_clock_new_single_shot_id() or gst_clock_new_periodic_id() and should not have been unscheduled with a call to gst_clock_id_unschedule().
If the @jitter argument is not %NULL and this function returns #GST_CLOCK_OK or #GST_CLOCK_EARLY, it will contain the difference against the clock and the time of @id when this method was called. Positive values indicate how late @id was relative to the clock (in which case this function will return #GST_CLOCK_EARLY). Negative values indicate how much time was spent waiting on the clock before this function returned.

parameter.name: jitter
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer that will contain the jitter, can be %NULL.

function.return:
the result of the blocking wait. #GST_CLOCK_EARLY will be returned if the current clock time is past the time of @id, #GST_CLOCK_OK if @id was scheduled in time. #GST_CLOCK_UNSCHEDULED if @id was unscheduled with gst_clock_id_unschedule().
MT safe.

function.name: gst_clock_id_wait_async
function.description:
Register a callback on the given #GstClockID @id with the given function and user_data. When passing a #GstClockID with an invalid time to this function, the callback will be called immediately with a time set to GST_CLOCK_TIME_NONE. The callback will be called when the time of @id has been reached.
The callback @func can be invoked from any thread, either provided by the core or from a streaming thread. The application should be prepared for this.

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: User data passed in the callback

function.return:
the result of the non blocking wait.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_clock_id_wait_async_full
function.description:
Register a callback on the given #GstClockID @id with the given function and user_data. When passing a #GstClockID with an invalid time to this function, the callback will be called immediately with a time set to GST_CLOCK_TIME_NONE. The callback will be called when the time of @id has been reached.
The callback @func can be invoked from any thread, either provided by the core or from a streaming thread. The application should be prepared for this.

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: User data passed in the callback

function.return:
the result of the non blocking wait.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_clock_new_periodic_id
function.description:
Get an ID from @clock to trigger a periodic notification. The periodic notifications will start at time @start_time and will then be fired with the given @interval. @id should be unreffed after usage.
Free-function: gst_clock_id_unref

parameter.name: clock
parameter.parameter_description: The #GstClockID to get a periodic notification id from

function.return:
a #GstClockID that can be used to request the time notification.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_clock_new_single_shot_id
function.description:
Get a #GstClockID from @clock to trigger a single shot notification at the requested time. The single shot id should be unreffed after usage.
Free-function: gst_clock_id_unref

parameter.name: clock
parameter.parameter_description: The #GstClockID to get a single shot notification from

function.return:
a #GstClockID that can be used to request the time notification.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_clock_periodic_id_reinit
function.description: Reinitializes the provided periodic @id to the provided start time and interval. Does not modify the reference count.
function.return: %TRUE if the GstClockID could be reinitialized to the provided @time, else %FALSE.

function.name: gst_clock_set_calibration
function.description:
Adjusts the rate and time of @clock. A rate of 1/1 is the normal speed of the clock. Values bigger than 1/1 make the clock go faster.
@internal and @external are calibration parameters that arrange that gst_clock_get_time() should have been @external at internal time @internal. This internal time should not be in the future; that is, it should be less than the value of gst_clock_get_internal_time() when this function is called.
Subsequent calls to gst_clock_get_time() will return clock times computed as follows:
<programlisting> time = (internal_time - internal) * rate_num / rate_denom + external </programlisting>
This formula is implemented in gst_clock_adjust_unlocked(). Of course, it tries to do the integer arithmetic as precisely as possible.
Note that gst_clock_get_time() always returns increasing values so when you move the clock backwards, gst_clock_get_time() will report the previous value until the clock catches up.
MT safe.

parameter.name: rate_num
parameter.parameter_description: the numerator of the rate of the clock relative to its internal time

parameter.name: rate_denom
parameter.parameter_description: the denominator of the rate of the clock

function.name: gst_clock_set_master
function.return:
%TRUE if the clock is capable of being slaved to a master clock. Trying to set a master on a clock without the #GST_CLOCK_FLAG_CAN_SET_MASTER flag will make this function return %FALSE.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_clock_set_resolution
function.description: Set the accuracy of the clock. Some clocks have the possibility to operate with different accuracy at the expense of more resource usage. There is normally no need to change the default resolution of a clock. The resolution of a clock can only be changed if the clock has the #GST_CLOCK_FLAG_CAN_SET_RESOLUTION flag set.
function.return: the new resolution of the clock.

function.name: gst_clock_single_shot_id_reinit
function.description: Reinitializes the provided single shot @id to the provided time. Does not modify the reference count.
function.return: %TRUE if the GstClockID could be reinitialized to the provided @time, else %FALSE.

function.name: gst_clock_unadjust_unlocked
function.description:
Converts the given @external clock time to the internal time of @clock, using the rate and reference time set with gst_clock_set_calibration(). This function should be called with the clock's OBJECT_LOCK held and is mainly used by clock subclasses.
This function is the reverse of gst_clock_adjust_unlocked().
function.return: the internal time of the clock corresponding to @external.

function.name: gst_codec_utils_aac_caps_set_level_and_profile

parameter.name: caps
parameter.parameter_description: the #GstCaps to which level and profile fields are to be added

parameter.name: audio_config
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to the AudioSpecificConfig as specified in the Elementary Stream Descriptor (esds) in ISO/IEC 14496-1 (see below for a more details).

function.return: %TRUE if the level and profile could be set, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gst_codec_utils_aac_get_level
function.description:
Determines the level of a stream as defined in ISO/IEC 14496-3. For AAC LC streams, the constraints from the AAC audio profile are applied. For AAC Main, LTP, SSR and others, the Main profile is used.
The @audio_config parameter follows the following format, starting from the most significant bit of the first byte:
<itemizedlist> <listitem><para> Bit 0:4 contains the AudioObjectType </para></listitem> <listitem><para> Bit 5:8 contains the sample frequency index (if this is 0xf, then the next 24 bits define the actual sample frequency, and subsequent fields are appropriately shifted). </para></listitem> <listitem><para> Bit 9:12 contains the channel configuration </para></listitem> </itemizedlist>
<note> HE-AAC support has not yet been implemented. </note>

parameter.name: audio_config
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to the AudioSpecificConfig as specified in the Elementary Stream Descriptor (esds) in ISO/IEC 14496-1.

function.return: The level as a const string and %NULL if the level could not be determined.

function.name: gst_codec_utils_aac_get_profile
function.description:
Returns the profile of the given AAC stream as a string. The profile is determined using the AudioObjectType field which is in the first 5 bits of @audio_config.
<note> HE-AAC support has not yet been implemented. </note>

parameter.name: audio_config
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to the AudioSpecificConfig as specified in the Elementary Stream Descriptor (esds) in ISO/IEC 14496-1 (see gst_codec_utils_aac_get_level() for a more details).

function.return: The profile as a const string and %NULL if the profile could not be determined.

function.name: gst_codec_utils_aac_get_sample_rate_from_index
function.description: Translates the sample rate index found in AAC headers to the actual sample rate.

parameter.name: sr_idx
parameter.parameter_description: Sample rate index as from the AudioSpecificConfig (MPEG-4 container) or ADTS frame header

function.return: The sample rate if @sr_idx is valid, 0 otherwise.

function.name: gst_codec_utils_h264_caps_set_level_and_profile
function.description: Sets the level and profile in @caps if it can be determined from @sps. See gst_codec_utils_h264_get_level() and gst_codec_utils_h264_get_profile() for more details on the parameters.

parameter.name: caps
parameter.parameter_description: the #GstCaps to which the level and profile are to be added

parameter.name: sps
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to the sequence parameter set for the stream.

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: Length of the data available in @sps.

function.return: %TRUE if the level and profile could be set, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gst_codec_utils_h264_get_level
function.description: Converts the level indication (level_idc) in the stream's sequence parameter set into a string. The SPS is expected to have the same format as for gst_codec_utils_h264_get_profile().

parameter.name: sps
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to the sequence parameter set for the stream.

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: Length of the data available in @sps.

function.return: The level as a const string, or %NULL if there is an error.

function.name: gst_codec_utils_h264_get_profile
function.description:
Converts the profile indication (profile_idc) in the stream's sequence parameter set into a string. The SPS is expected to have the following format, as defined in the H.264 specification. The SPS is viewed as a bitstream here, with bit 0 being the most significant bit of the first byte.
<itemizedlist> <listitem><para>Bit 0:7 - Profile indication</para></listitem> <listitem><para>Bit 8 - constraint_set0_flag</para></listitem> <listitem><para>Bit 9 - constraint_set1_flag</para></listitem> <listitem><para>Bit 10 - constraint_set2_flag</para></listitem> <listitem><para>Bit 11 - constraint_set3_flag</para></listitem> <listitem><para>Bit 12 - constraint_set3_flag</para></listitem> <listitem><para>Bit 13:15 - Reserved</para></listitem> <listitem><para>Bit 16:24 - Level indication</para></listitem> </itemizedlist>

parameter.name: sps
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to the sequence parameter set for the stream.

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: Length of the data available in @sps.

function.return: The profile as a const string, or %NULL if there is an error.

function.name: gst_codec_utils_mpeg4video_caps_set_level_and_profile
function.description: Sets the level and profile in @caps if it can be determined from @vis_obj_seq. See gst_codec_utils_mpeg4video_get_level() and gst_codec_utils_mpeg4video_get_profile() for more details on the parameters.

parameter.name: caps
parameter.parameter_description: the #GstCaps to which the level and profile are to be added

parameter.name: vis_obj_seq
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to the visual object sequence for the stream.

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: Length of the data available in @sps.

function.return: %TRUE if the level and profile could be set, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gst_codec_utils_mpeg4video_get_level
function.description: Converts the level indication in the stream's visual object sequence into a string. @vis_obj_seq is expected to be the data following the visual object sequence start code. Only the first byte (profile_and_level_indication) is used.

parameter.name: vis_obj_seq
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to the visual object sequence for the stream.

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: Length of the data available in @sps.

function.return: The level as a const string, or NULL if there is an error.

function.name: gst_codec_utils_mpeg4video_get_profile
function.description: Converts the profile indication in the stream's visual object sequence into a string. @vis_obj_seq is expected to be the data following the visual object sequence start code. Only the first byte (profile_and_level_indication) is used.

parameter.name: vis_obj_seq
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to the visual object sequence for the stream.

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: Length of the data available in @sps.

function.return: The profile as a const string, or NULL if there is an error.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_add_pad
function.description:
Add a pad to the collection of collect pads. The pad has to be a sinkpad. The refcount of the pad is incremented. Use gst_collect_pads_remove_pad() to remove the pad from the collection again.
This function will override the chain and event functions of the pad along with the element_private data, which is used to store private information for the collectpads.
You specify a size for the returned #GstCollectData structure so that you can use it to store additional information.
The pad will be automatically activated in push mode when @pads is started.
This function calls gst_collect_pads_add_pad_full() passing a value of NULL for destroy_notify.
MT safe.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: the size of the returned #GstCollectData structure

function.return: a new #GstCollectData to identify the new pad. Or NULL if wrong parameters are supplied.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_add_pad_full
function.description:
Add a pad to the collection of collect pads. The pad has to be a sinkpad. The refcount of the pad is incremented. Use gst_collect_pads_remove_pad() to remove the pad from the collection again.
You specify a size for the returned #GstCollectData structure so that you can use it to store additional information.
You can also specify a #GstCollectDataDestroyNotify that will be called just before the #GstCollectData structure is freed. It is passed the pointer to the structure and should free any custom memory and resources allocated for it.
The pad will be automatically activated in push mode when @pads is started.
MT safe.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: the size of the returned #GstCollectData structure

parameter.name: destroy_notify
parameter.parameter_description: function to be called before the returned #GstCollectData structure is freed

function.return: a new #GstCollectData to identify the new pad. Or NULL if wrong parameters are supplied.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_available
function.description:
Query how much bytes can be read from each queued buffer. This means that the result of this call is the maximum number of bytes that can be read from each of the pads.
This function should be called with @pads LOCK held, such as in the callback.
MT safe.
function.return: The maximum number of bytes queued on all pads. This function returns 0 if a pad has no queued buffer.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_collect
function.description:
Collect data on all pads. This function is usually called from a #GstTask function in an element.
This function is currently not implemented.
MT safe.
function.return: #GstFlowReturn of the operation.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_collect_range
function.description:
Collect data with @offset and @length on all pads. This function is typically called in the getrange function of an element.
This function is currently not implemented.
MT safe.
function.return: #GstFlowReturn of the operation.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_flush
function.description:
Flush @size bytes from the pad @data.
This function should be called with @pads LOCK held, such as in the callback.
MT safe.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: the number of bytes to flush

function.return: The number of bytes flushed. This can be less than @size and is 0 if the pad was end-of-stream.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_is_active
function.description:
Check if a pad is active.
This function is currently not implemented.
MT safe.
function.return: %TRUE if the pad is active.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_new
function.description:
Create a new instance of #GstCollectPads.
MT safe.
function.return: a new #GstCollectPads, or NULL in case of an error.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_peek
function.description:
Peek at the buffer currently queued in @data. This function should be called with the @pads LOCK held, such as in the callback handler.
MT safe.
function.return: The buffer in @data or NULL if no buffer is queued. should unref the buffer after usage.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_pop
function.description:
Pop the buffer currently queued in @data. This function should be called with the @pads LOCK held, such as in the callback handler.
Free-function: gst_buffer_unref
MT safe.
function.return: The buffer in @data or NULL if no buffer was queued. You should unref the buffer after usage.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_read
function.description:
Get a pointer in @bytes where @size bytes can be read from the given pad @data.
This function should be called with @pads LOCK held, such as in the callback.
MT safe.

parameter.name: bytes
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a byte array

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: the number of bytes to read

function.return: The number of bytes available for consumption in the memory pointed to by @bytes. This can be less than @size and is 0 if the pad is end-of-stream.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_read_buffer
function.description:
Get a buffer of @size bytes from the given pad @data.
This function should be called with @pads LOCK held, such as in the callback.
Free-function: gst_buffer_unref

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: the number of bytes to read

function.return:
a #GstBuffer. The size of the buffer can be less that requested. A return of NULL signals that the pad is end-of-stream. Unref the buffer with gst_buffer_unref() after use.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_remove_pad
function.description:
Remove a pad from the collection of collect pads. This function will also free the #GstCollectData and all the resources that were allocated with gst_collect_pads_add_pad().
The pad will be deactivated automatically when @pads is stopped.
MT safe.
function.return: %TRUE if the pad could be removed.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_set_clip_function
function.description: Install a clipping function that is called right after a buffer is received on a pad managed by @pads. See #GstCollectPadsClipFunction for more info.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_set_flushing
function.description:
Change the flushing state of all the pads in the collection. No pad is able to accept anymore data when @flushing is %TRUE. Calling this function with @flushing %FALSE makes @pads accept data again.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_set_function
function.description:
Set the callback function and user data that will be called when all the pads added to the collection have buffers queued.
MT safe.

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data passed to the function

function.name: gst_collect_pads_start
function.description:
Starts the processing of data in the collect_pads.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_stop
function.description:
Stops the processing of data in the collect_pads. this function will also unblock any blocking operations.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_collect_pads_take_buffer
function.description:
Get a buffer of @size bytes from the given pad @data. Flushes the amount of read bytes.
This function should be called with @pads LOCK held, such as in the callback.
Free-function: gst_buffer_unref
MT safe.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: the number of bytes to read

function.return: a #GstBuffer. The size of the buffer can be less that requested. A return of NULL signals that the pad is end-of-stream. Unref the buffer after use.

function.name: gst_color_balance_get_balance_type
function.description: Get the #GstColorBalanceType of this implementation.
function.return: A the #GstColorBalanceType.

function.name: gst_color_balance_get_value
function.description:
Retrieve the current value of the indicated channel, between min_value and max_value.
See Also: The #GstColorBalanceChannel::min_value and #GstColorBalanceChannel::max_value members of the #GstColorBalanceChannel object.
function.return: The current value of the channel.

function.name: gst_color_balance_list_channels
function.description: Retrieve a list of the available channels.
function.return: A GList containing pointers to #GstColorBalanceChannel objects. The list is owned by the #GstColorBalance instance and must not be freed.

function.name: gst_color_balance_set_value
function.description:
Sets the current value of the channel to the passed value, which must be between min_value and max_value.
See Also: The #GstColorBalanceChannel::min_value and #GstColorBalanceChannel::max_value members of the #GstColorBalanceChannel object.

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: The new value for the channel.

function.name: gst_color_balance_value_changed
function.description: A helper function called by implementations of the GstColorBalance interface. It fires the #GstColorBalance::value-changed signal on the instance, and the #GstColorBalanceChannel::value-changed signal on the channel object.

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: The new value of the channel

function.name: gst_consistency_checker_free
function.description: Frees the allocated data and probe associated with @consist.

function.name: gst_consistency_checker_new
function.description:
Sets up a data probe on the given pad which will raise assertions if the data flow is inconsistent.
Currently only works for source pads.

parameter.name: pad
parameter.parameter_description: The #GstPad on which the dataflow will be checked.

function.return: A #GstStreamConsistency structure used to track data flow.

function.name: gst_consistency_checker_reset
function.description: Reset the stream checker's internal variables.

function.name: gst_control_source_bind
function.description: Binds a #GstControlSource to a specific property. This must be called only once for a #GstControlSource.

parameter.name: pspec
parameter.parameter_description: #GParamSpec for the property for which this #GstControlSource should generate values.

function.return: %TRUE if the #GstControlSource was bound correctly, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gst_control_source_get_value
function.description: Gets the value for this #GstControlSource at a given timestamp.

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: the time for which the value should be returned

function.return: FALSE if the value couldn't be returned, TRUE otherwise.

function.name: gst_control_source_get_value_array
function.description:
Gets an array of values for one element property.
All fields of @value_array must be filled correctly. Especially the @value_array->values array must be big enough to keep the requested amount of values.
The type of the values in the array is the same as the property's type.

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: the time that should be processed

function.return: %TRUE if the given array could be filled, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gst_controller_get
function.description: Gets the value for the given controller-handled property at the requested time.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the controller object which handles the properties

parameter.name: property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the property to get

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: the time the control-change should be read from

function.return: the GValue of the property at the given time, or %NULL if the property isn't handled by the controller

function.name: gst_controller_get_all
function.description:
Returns a read-only copy of the list of #GstTimedValue for the given property. Free the list after done with it.
<note><para>This doesn't modify the controlled GObject property!</para></note>
Deprecated: Use #GstControlSource, for example #GstInterpolationControlSource directly.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the controller to get the list from

parameter.name: property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the property to get the list for

function.return: a copy of the list, or %NULL if the property isn't handled by the controller

function.name: gst_controller_get_control_source
function.description: Gets the corresponding #GstControlSource for the property. This should be unreferenced again after use.

parameter.name: property_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of the property for which the #GstControlSource should be get

function.return: the #GstControlSource for @property_name or NULL if the property is not controlled by this controller or no #GstControlSource was assigned yet.

function.name: gst_controller_get_value_array
function.description:
Function to be able to get an array of values for one element property.
All fields of @value_array must be filled correctly. Especially the @value_array->values array must be big enough to keep the requested amount of values (as indicated by the nbsamples field).
The type of the values in the array is the same as the property's type.
<note><para>This doesn't modify the controlled GObject property!</para></note>

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the controller that handles the values

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: the time that should be processed

function.return: %TRUE if the given array could be filled, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gst_controller_get_value_arrays
function.description:
Function to be able to get an array of values for one or more given element properties.
All fields of the %GstValueArray in the list must be filled correctly. Especially the GstValueArray->values arrays must be big enough to keep the requested amount of values.
The types of the values in the array are the same as the property's type.
<note><para>This doesn't modify the controlled GObject properties!</para></note>

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the controller that handles the values

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: the time that should be processed

parameter.name: value_arrays
parameter.parameter_description: list to return the control-values in

function.return: %TRUE if the given array(s) could be filled, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gst_controller_init
function.description: Initializes the use of the controller library. Suggested to be called right after gst_init().

parameter.name: argc
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to the commandline argument count

parameter.name: argv
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to the commandline argument values

function.return: the %TRUE for success.

function.name: gst_controller_new
function.description: Creates a new GstController for the given object's properties

parameter.name: object
parameter.parameter_description: the object of which some properties should be controlled

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: %NULL terminated list of property names that should be controlled

function.return: the new controller.

function.name: gst_controller_new_list
function.description: Creates a new GstController for the given object's properties

parameter.name: object
parameter.parameter_description: the object of which some properties should be controlled

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: list of property names that should be controlled

function.return: the new controller.

function.name: gst_controller_new_valist
function.description: Creates a new GstController for the given object's properties

parameter.name: object
parameter.parameter_description: the object of which some properties should be controlled

parameter.name: var_args
parameter.parameter_description: %NULL terminated list of property names that should be controlled

function.return: the new controller.

function.name: gst_controller_remove_properties
function.description: Removes the given object properties from the controller

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the controller object from which some properties should be removed

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: %NULL terminated list of property names that should be removed

function.return: %FALSE if one of the given property isn't handled by the controller, %TRUE otherwise

function.name: gst_controller_remove_properties_list
function.description: Removes the given object properties from the controller

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the controller object from which some properties should be removed

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: #GList of property names that should be removed

function.return: %FALSE if one of the given property isn't handled by the controller, %TRUE otherwise

function.name: gst_controller_remove_properties_valist
function.description: Removes the given object properties from the controller

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the controller object from which some properties should be removed

parameter.name: var_args
parameter.parameter_description: %NULL terminated list of property names that should be removed

function.return: %FALSE if one of the given property isn't handled by the controller, %TRUE otherwise

function.name: gst_controller_set
function.description:
Set the value of given controller-handled property at a certain time.
Deprecated: Use #GstControlSource, for example #GstInterpolationControlSource directly.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the controller object which handles the properties

parameter.name: property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the property to set

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: the time the control-change is schedules for

function.return: FALSE if the values couldn't be set (ex : properties not handled by controller), TRUE otherwise

function.name: gst_controller_set_control_source
function.description: Sets the #GstControlSource for @property_name. If there already was a #GstControlSource for this property it will be unreferenced.

parameter.name: property_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of the property for which the #GstControlSource should be set

parameter.name: csource
parameter.parameter_description: the #GstControlSource that should be used for the property

function.return: %FALSE if the given property isn't handled by the controller or the new #GstControlSource couldn't be bound to the property, %TRUE if everything worked as expected.

function.name: gst_controller_set_disabled
function.description: This function is used to disable all properties of the #GstController for some time, i.e. gst_controller_sync_values() will do nothing.

parameter.name: disabled
parameter.parameter_description: boolean that specifies whether to disable the controller or not.

function.name: gst_controller_set_from_list
function.description:
Sets multiple timed values at once.
Deprecated: Use #GstControlSource, for example #GstInterpolationControlSource directly.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the controller object which handles the properties

parameter.name: property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the property to set

function.return: %FALSE if the values couldn't be set (ex : properties not handled by controller), %TRUE otherwise

function.name: gst_controller_set_interpolation_mode
function.description:
Sets the given interpolation mode on the given property.
<note><para>User interpolation is not yet available and quadratic interpolation is deprecated and maps to cubic interpolation.</para></note>
Deprecated: Use #GstControlSource, for example #GstInterpolationControlSource directly.

parameter.name: property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the property for which to change the interpolation

function.return: %TRUE if the property is handled by the controller, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gst_controller_set_property_disabled
function.description: This function is used to disable the #GstController on a property for some time, i.e. gst_controller_sync_values() will do nothing for the property.

parameter.name: disabled
parameter.parameter_description: boolean that specifies whether to disable the controller or not.

function.name: gst_controller_suggest_next_sync
function.description: Returns a suggestion for timestamps where buffers should be split to get best controller results.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the controller that handles the values

function.return: Returns the suggested timestamp or %GST_CLOCK_TIME_NONE if no control-rate was set.

function.name: gst_controller_sync_values
function.description:
Sets the properties of the element, according to the controller that (maybe) handles them and for the given timestamp.
If this function fails, it is most likely the application developers fault. Most probably the control sources are not setup correctly.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the controller that handles the values

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: the time that should be processed

function.return: %TRUE if the controller values could be applied to the object properties, %FALSE otherwise
